Proposal: 1445992
PI: Wax, Adam
Institution: Duke University
Title: EAGER: Cell phone enabled spectroscopy

Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT) systems have become an essential retinal imaging tool for ophthalmologists but their cost of up to $150,000 for clinical systems has restricted access to only large eye centers. There is significant opportunity for using OCT at the point of care, if a low cost instrument were available. The lower cost will permit use of OCT technology by a wider range of physicians and optometrists. The technology and innovation in this project will enable low cost novel mobile health applications currently unavailable.

The goal of this EAGER proposal is to create a low cost, high performance spectrometer based on line scan sensors typically used for fingerprint scanners in cell phones. Many cell phones incorporate fingerprint scanners based on a variety of sensing methods. Most fingerprint scanners use an optical sensor, which are an ideal format for spectroscopy with single line high pixel count sensor elements. In this project the PI seeks to demonstrate proof of principle using an optical fingerprint scanner for high performance spectroscopy. The proposed spectrometer will be low cost (<$500) and enable high resolution spectroscopy as well as fast signal acquisition. To demonstrate the utility of the proposed platform, they will create a spectrometer design suitable for spectral domain optical coherence tomography (SD-OCT).

por.por_cntn:
EAGER: Cell phone enabled spectroscopy

Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT) has become a widespread tool used by ophthalmologists for retinal imaging.  However, the cost of OCT systems of up to $150,000 has limited access to only large eye centers. There is a large potential benefit for using OCT at the point of care, if a low cost instrument were available. Lower cost will permit use of OCT technology by a wider range of physicians and optometrists. The technology and innovation developed in this project will enable lower cost OCT systems and provide greater access to this imaging tool. The broader impact of this research will be the access to this imaging tool, particularly in low resource settings.

The  EAGER project has created a low cost device that is a key component for OCT systems, namely a high performance spectrometer which can separate light based on its wavelength.  The approach is based on line scan sensors typically used for fingerprint scanners in cell phones which has helped keep the cost of the instrument extremely low. Many fingerprint scanners use an optical sensor which is just one pixel tall but several thousand pixels across.  This format is ideal for spectroscopy but especially for OCT. In this project we have shown a proof of principle using an optical fingerprint scanner for high performance spectrometer. The spectrometer has a pathway to be low cost in production (<$500) although the initial prototype had to rely on off the shelf parts which increased the cost to $1500.  A key parameter that makes this spectrometer well suited for OCT is that it offers fast signal acquisition. This in turn means that an OCT system based on this spectrometer can provide rapid image updates.  We have demonstrated the utility of this spectrometer design by incorporating it into an optical coherence tomography system. The intellectual merit of this project is the realization of a low cost spectrometer design with sufficient performance to use for OCT. The attached figure shows an image of the implemented OCT system.
